subject: As Iran moves ahead with their nuclear program,  the US is secretly working to sabotage it. Don't miss our Exclusive report tonight on the CBS Evening News with Katie Couric.
body:
CBSNews.com


 









  Home | U.S. | World | Politics | SciTech | Health | Entertainment | Business | Opinion | Sports | Blogs | Interactives | Video 

  The Early Show | CBS Evening News | 48 Hours | 60 Minutes | The Saturday Early Show | CBS Sunday Morning | Face The Nation 






QUOTE OF THE DAY"You cannot depend on your eyes 
      when your imagination is out of focus." - Mark Twain 
      



DID YOU KNOW?Gunsmoke debuted on 
      CBS-TV in 1955, and went on to become the longest-running (20 years) 
      series on television. 



TONIGHT ON THE CBS EVENING NEWSHere is an early 
      preview of what we are planning for tonight's CBS EVENING NEWS from Anchor 
      and Managing Editor, Katie Couric... Hi everyone, 
      We'll begin tonight's broadcast with an exclusive report on secret 
      efforts to delay Iran's moves to acquire and develop nuclear technology. 
      Sheila MacVicar will have the story, and David Martin will 
      fill in more details about our country's volatile relationship with Iran. 
      In Iraq, the search for the three U.S. soldiers seized two weeks 
      ago continues. Today, the hunt yielded a body that Iraqi police believe to 
      be one of the missing soldiers. Mark Strassmann reports that the 
      military continues the search while investigators hurry to find more clues 
      and identify the body. At home, the summer travel season is 
      rapidly approaching, and the Federal Aviation Administration announced a 
      new program that is aimed to help better navigate the upcoming stormy 
      summer months. Could it work? Nancy Cordes will report. If 
      you're an individual in the United States seeking medical insurance 
      coverage, the odds are stacked wildly against you. Our investigative team 
      has been probing the sometimes questionable tactics used by insurance 
      companies, and tonight Armen Keteyian will have our report. 
      Finally, Sandra Hughes will report that concern is growing 
      for the safety of the wayward whale duo dubbed Delta and Dawn, as they 
      have been circling near a Sacramento River bridge. Scientists analyzing 
      photographs of the mother-and-calf pair say their appearance indicates 
      declining health. We'll have more details on these whales and what others 
      of their species to get themselves in situations like this. 
      I hope you'll join us. Katie For 
      more information on these stories, please click on the following 
      links: U.N.: Iran Enriching More, Closing Doors Click 
      Here Making A Raucous Noise Unto The Whales Click 
      Here And here's a look at one of the stories we're working 
      on for Thursday's broadcast: A CBS News Investigation... 16 
      million Americans have what's called "individual health coverage"... or 
      THINK they do. This story and much more, Thursday, on the CBS 
      Evening News. If you would like more information on any of 
      these stories or the broadcast, please click on the following address and 
      e-mail us: evening@cbsnews.com 
      


TONIGHT ON DAVID 
      LETTERMANJoin Dave tonight on The Late 
      Show with actress Rosie Perez... And don't miss seeing these 
      stupid pet tricks. Plus, musical guest Dr. Dog! 



 
THURSDAY 
      MORNING ON THE EARLY SHOW
Harry Smith, Hannah Storm, 
      Julie Chen and Russ Mitchell anchor THE EARLY 
      SHOW from New York. John Bolaris, of 
      our New York affiliate, WCBS, will bring us the weather. Dave Price 
      is on assignment. Along with the top news of the day, we will 
      also have the following stories: AMERICAN IDOL WINNER: 
      Wednesday night, Blake Lewis and Jordin Sparks learn their fate as one is 
      named the next American Idol. What did your votes decide? And did America 
      get it right? E! Entertainment anchor and EARLY 
      SHOW Special Correspondent Giuliana 
      DePandi will join us with America's choice for singing stardom... and 
      the runner-up too. HAPPILY EVER AFTER, PART 4: Twins Runda 
      and Randa Harris have rarely spent time apart. They went to prom together, 
      modeled together, and when it came time for their weddings, they had a 
      double ceremony. The two couples made homes for themselves next door to 
      one another, so they would never be far from each other's sides. When 
      Hurricane Isabel struck, a 70-ft tree fell on Runda's husband, resulting 
      in traumatic brain injury. The incident tested their relationship and 
      showed the twins the power of family and love. We'll have this incredible 
      story Thursday morning. WYNTON MARSALIS: Wynton Marsalis 
      will join us to talk about his reunion concert with most of the original 
      members of the Wynton Marsalis Septet, commemorating the fifteenth 
      anniversary of the debut of the critically acclaimed In This House, On 
      This Morning. CSI MUSEUM OPENS IN CHICAGO: This Friday, 
      the CSI Museum is set to open its doors in the Windy City. 
      EARLY SHOW National Correspondent 
      Tracy Smith will have a sneak peek at all the sights and sounds 
      live from Chicago. YOUNG AT HEART: THE GOOD SPOUSE: Getting 
      older isn't for sissies. 90% of all senior citizens have at least one 
      chronic illness. Understanding and assistance from a spouse are crucial in 
      making the life adjustments these diseases require. But how can you be a 
      good spouse without nagging or interfering? Gabi Redford, features editor 
      for AARP The Magazine, will join us with advice. 
      WILLIAMS SONOMA: MEMORIAL DAY PICNIC: It's that time of 
      year! Memorial Day weekend. And for many, that means firing up the 
      backyard barbeque and grilling up a feat for friends and family. But if 
      grilling under the hot sun doesn't strike your fancy, you can have just as 
      much fun with a festive holiday picnic. Instead of packing the usual 
      sandwiches and potato salad for a Memorial Day picnic, our friend and 
      cookbook author Tori Ritchie will join us with some delicious 
      alternatives for the weekend. If you would like more information 
      on any of these stories or the broadcast, please click on the following 
      address and e-mail us: earlyshow@cbs.com
